ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Self-adaptive Mutation Rates, Novelty Search and CMA-ES

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Vassilis,

Thanks for the interest in, and excitement about, the firs=
t batch of Evolving AI Lab publications. :-)

As for CMA-ES, I did not unde=
rstand from your email if it is indeed self-adaptive. It seems like you sai=
d that the fitness of organisms does not affect the mutation rate (the issu=
e of =93unbiasedness=94). That would certainly make the problem of self-ada=
ptive mutation rates go away! 

You also mention the 1/5th rule, which is n=
ot self-adaptive: it does not have a mutation rate is on each genome that h=
itchhikes along with the other parameters on the genome. 

Does CMA-ES do s=
omething different? I couldn=92t discern the answer from your notion. For e=
xample, in CMA-ES, is there a parameter that evolves that controls the numb=
er of mutations per genome per generation? I thought CMA-ES didn=92t even h=
ave a population of individuals, so I=92m not sure how it could even have s=
elf-adaptive mutation rates.


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professo=
r
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

=
On May 4, 2014, at 8:00 AM, Vassilis Vassiliades <vassilisvas@...> wr=
ote:

> 
> Hello all,
> 
> Joel and Ken, I think I understand what you are =
saying about "projecting intuitions about the objective world into novelty =
search" and the dynamic and divergent nature of Novelty Search (NS)... and =
also why naively combining Covariance Matrix Adaptation - Evolution Strateg=
ies (CMA-ES) might not work well with NS. A "fitness" peak in generation (g=
) might diminish in generation (g+1), and generally the "fitness" peaks are=
 constantly moving.
> 
> This reminds me a bit of multiagent learning probl=
ems, where one could say that the "target" is constantly and adaptively bei=
ng moved. However, I am not sure whether/how we could frame NS as a multiag=
ent learning scenario. I am also imagining the landscape of NS as a... "boi=
ling soup" where bubbles (fitness peaks) keep appearing and disappearing al=
l the time. :) These bubbles could be guided by the archive, so that they w=
ould never appear at the same place, or if we were to bound the archive (or=
 use the probabilistic approach), they could appear again after some time (=
or probabilistically). 
> 
> Questions:
> 
> 1) Does anyone think that ther=
e is any relationship of NS with thermodynamics?
> 
> 2) Do you think there=
 are any relationships between NS and dynamic optimization?
> 
> 3) Joel, y=
ou often mention competitive coevolution when talking about NS. You also sa=
id that "there exist similar fixed-point concepts for competitive co-evolut=
ion (like mediocre stable states and disengagement)". To be honest, I haven=
't read the literature on these concepts. I was thinking, however, that if =
we were to think about coevolution in game theoretic terms, then competitiv=
e coevolution is like a zero-sum game: the gains of one individual are bala=
nced by the losses of the others. Is this correct? Does NS behave in this m=
anner? It seems to me that it is not a zero-sum game.
> 
> 
> 
> Jeff, I ag=
ree with you that CMA-ES learns correlations. However, allow me to express =
here my understanding as to how it works and its relationship to self-adapt=
ive mutation rates (SAMR). * I included this part at the end of the email b=
ecause it got very big :) Anyone who read this please do correct me if some=
thing is wrong.
> 
> Jeff you wrote: "my guess is that if you tried CMA-ES =
with and without a mutation rate on the genome, you=92d get the same result=
 I report in my paper". CMA-ES by construction uses the mutation rates. It =
is an important part of the algorithm. I would be very curious to see how C=
MA-ES behaves in the same setup used in your paper.
> 
> I noticed somethin=
g in your paper on SAMR. I also noticed that in Joel's and Ken's paper on S=
AMR with NS (which I still haven't read very carefully, only skimmed though=
): in both papers the SAMR are updated differently than the SAMR of ES (see=
 at the end of the email). Do you think that using an ES approach for SAMR =
in your setups would lead to any different results/conclusions?
> 
> "'nove=
lty plateaus', a concept my students and I introduce in our last, not-yet-a=
nnounced GECCO paper"
> Sounds interesting! Congrats by the way on all new =
papers!
> 
> 
> 
> Ken Lloyd, thanks for the link on Adaptive Stochastic Re=
sonance. I haven't read it yet, but I also noticed that there are several w=
orks that have similarities with NS (e.g., intrinsic motivations, maximizat=
ion of predictive information, causal entropic forces, empowerment etc.). D=
oes anyone think it would it be interesting to crowdsource a list of simila=
r works on a different thread? I think Joel and Ken (Stanley) probably know=
 a lot of them already.
> 
> 
> 
> Oliver, you mentioned "some work has pro=
babilistically applied the objective function". I would be interested to se=
e this work if you find the link. If I remember correctly Jeff, JBM and Hod=
 Lipson in "The evolutionary origins of modularity" used something similar,=
 but on the secondary objective (connection cost) objective.
> 
> 
> 
> Bes=
t,
> Vassilis
> 
> 
> * Notes on CMA-ES:
> 
> In evolution strategies (ES) =
the mutation operator is usually the primary source of variation. Thus, we =
could say that while selection exploits the fitness information in order to=
 guide search into promising regions, mutation (or variation) explores the =
search space and should not use any fitness information to do that, i.e., i=
t should be unbiased. This is a theoretical consideration/requirement (call=
ed "unbiasedness"), which naturally leads to the maximum entropy principle.=
 In the case of real-valued search spaces this leads to gaussian distributi=
ons, while it has been also shown in the literature how to potentially hand=
le integer and discrete parameters.
> 
> Let's stay on real-valued spaces a=
nd let's say that an individual "a" comprises an object parameter vector "x=
", and its fitness function value "F(x)": a =3D (x, F(x)). Mutations on x w=
ork like this:
> 
> x' =3D x + z
> 
> with z being related to gaussian dist=
ributions. 
> 
> The simplest case is z =3D sigma * ( N_1(0,1), N_2(0,1), .=
.. , N_d(0,1) ), where sigma is the standard deviation of the normal distri=
bution, d is the dimensionality, and N_i(0,1) are independent random sample=
s from the normal distribution.
> 
> People have noticed that when sigma is=
 constant and the very simple (1+1)-ES is used (meaning 1 parent creates 1 =
offspring and the strongest of them survives), then in very simplified unim=
odal fitness functions (such as the sphere function), the ES initially disp=
lays a period of improvements; however, after a while it becomes very very =
slow and loses its evolvability because when approaching the minimum sigma =
is too big and tends to overshoot. By analyzing how sigma influences the su=
ccess probability by which an offspring replaces a parent, as well as the p=
rogress rate, people have come up with something called the "evolution wind=
ow" as well as the 1/5th control rule that appropriately scales sigma perio=
dically.
> 
> Now, the 1/5th rule is a heuristic and very specific to (1+1)=
-ES and the fitness landscape, so people needed something better. Hence the=
 following idea: 
> 
> Let's add an endogenous/evolvable strategy parameter=
 vector "s" to the individual, that contains any other parameters we want (=
such as the standard deviation). So now an individual is: a =3D (x,s,F(x)).=
 But how do we update sigma / the standard deviation? How do we mutate this=
 mutation strength/rate? The maximum entropy principle specifies that we sh=
ould use gaussian distributions, but using these on the standard deviation =
could lead to negative values. A neat solution is to do it in log scale:
> =

> ln( sigma' ) =3D ln( sigma ) + zeta
> 
> which leads to the multiplicati=
ve update:
> 
> sigma' =3D sigma * exp( zeta )
> 
> where zeta =3D tau * N(=
0,1), and tau is an exogenous learning parameter which determines the rate =
and precision of self-adaptation. It is usually proportional to 1/sqrt(d).
=
> 
> Until now we were talking about a single strategy parameter (mutation =
rate) for the whole genotype, i.e., s =3D sigma, also known as isotropic mu=
tations. We can extend this to the case where we have a vector of strategy =
parameters (mutation rates), i.e., s =3D (sigma_1, sigma_2, ..., sigma_d), =
also known as non-isotropic mutations. This technique is more flexible espe=
cially in high dimensional problems. However, it is still not very effectiv=
e in some non-separable problems, e.g., consider a fitness landscape that i=
s not aligned with the coordinate system. How do we deal with arbitrary rot=
ations of the fitness landscape, which is the most general situation?
> 
> =
Now the idea of Covariance Matrix Adaptation is introduced: let's estimate =
the shape of the fitness landscape and adapt a rotation matrix in order to =
be able to align our coordinate axes with the principal axes of the fitness=
 landscape. This covariance matrix introduces correlations between the comp=
onents of z.
> 
> So, in:
> 
> 1) isotropic mutations: z =3D sigma * ( N_1(=
0,1), N_2(0,1), ... , N_d(0,1) ) =3D sigma * N(0, I), where I is the identi=
ty matrix
> 
> 2) non-isotropic mutations: z =3D ( sigma_1 * N_1(0,1), sigm=
a_2 * N_2(0,1), ..., sigma_d * N_d(0,1) ) =3D D * N(0, I), where D is a dia=
gonal matrix containing all sigma values
> 
> 3) correlated mutations: z =
=3D M * ( sigma_1 * N_1(0,1), sigma_2 * N_2(0,1), ..., sigma_d * N_d(0,1) )=
 =3D M * D * N(0, I), where M is the rotation matrix that introduces correl=
ations between the components of z, and C =3D M^T * M is the covariance mat=
rix (M^T is the transpose of M).
> 
> 
> I won't get into more detail (e.g.=
, how to estimate the covariance matrix etc.), but note that CMA-ES has bee=
n shown to work very well in various benchmarks and with small population s=
izes.
> 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_AB005ED5-FB65-4F98-9309-4C3B2D354BCA

Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=windows-1252

y:none"> </span>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text"><div><br class=3D"webkit=
-block-placeholder"></div><div dir=3D"ltr"><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Hello=
 all,</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">=
Joel and Ken, I think I understand what you are saying about "projecting in=
tuitions about the objective world into novelty search" and the dynamic and=
 divergent nature of Novelty Search (NS)... and also why naively combining =
Covariance Matrix Adaptation - Evolution Strategies (CMA-ES) might not work=
 well with NS. A "fitness" peak in generation (g) might diminish in generat=
ion (g+1), and generally the "fitness" peaks are constantly moving.</div>
<=
div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">This reminds=
 me a bit of multiagent learning problems, where one could say that the "ta=
rget" is constantly and adaptively being moved. However, I am not sure whet=
her/how we could frame NS as a multiagent learning scenario. I am also imag=
ining the landscape of NS as a... "boiling soup" where bubbles (fitness pea=
ks) keep appearing and disappearing all the time. :) These bubbles could be=
 guided by the archive, so that they would never appear at the same place, =
or if we were to bound the archive (or use the probabilistic approach), the=
y could appear again after some time (or probabilistically). </div>
<d=
iv class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Questions:</d=
iv><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">1) Does =
anyone think that there is any relationship of NS with thermodynamics?</div=
><div class=3D"gmail_extra">
<br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">2) Do you=
 think there are any relationships between NS and dynamic optimization?</di=
v><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">3) Joel, =
you often mention competitive coevolution when talking about NS. You also s=
aid that "<span style=3D"font-family:arial,sans-serif;font-size:13px;">ther=
e exist similar fixed-point concepts for competitive co-evolution (like med=
iocre stable states and disengagement)". To be honest, I haven't read the l=
iterature on these concepts. I was thinking, however, that if we were to th=
ink about coevolution in game theoretic terms, then </span><span style=
=3D"font-family:arial,sans-serif;font-size:13px;">competitive coevolution i=
s like a zero-sum game: the gains of one individual are balanced by the los=
ses of the others. Is this correct? Does NS behave in this manner? It seems=
 to me that it is not a zero-sum game.</span></div>
<div class=3D"gmail_ext=
ra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extr=
a"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Jeff, I agree with you that CMA-ES =
learns correlations. However, allow me to express here my understanding as =
to how it works and its relationship to self-adaptive mutation rates (SAMR)=
. * I included this part at the end of the email because it got very big :)=
 Anyone who read this please do correct me if something is wrong.</div>
<di=
v class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Jeff you wrote=
: "my guess is that if you tried CMA-ES with and without a mutation rate on=
 the genome, you=92d get the same result I report in my paper". CMA-ES by c=
onstruction uses the mutation rates. It is an important part of the algorit=
hm. I would be very curious to see how CMA-ES behaves in the same setup use=
d in your paper.</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"g=
mail_extra">I noticed something in your paper on SAMR. I also noticed that =
in Joel's and Ken's paper on SAMR with NS (which I still haven't read very =
carefully, only skimmed though): in both papers the SAMR are updated differ=
ently than the SAMR of ES (see at the end of the email). Do you think that =
using an ES approach for SAMR in your setups would lead to any different re=
sults/conclusions?<br>
</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div clas=
s=3D"gmail_extra">"'novelty plateaus', a concept my students and I introduc=
e in our last, not-yet-announced GECCO paper"</div><div class=3D"gmail_extr=
a">Sounds interesting! Congrats by the way on all new papers!</div>
<div cl=
ass=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div cla=
ss=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Ken Lloyd, thanks f=
or the link on Adaptive Stochastic Resonance. I haven't read it yet, but I =
also noticed that there are several works that have similarities with NS (e=
.g., intrinsic motivations, maximization of predictive information, causal =
entropic forces, empowerment etc.). Does anyone think it would it be intere=
sting to crowdsource a list of similar works on a different thread? I think=
 Joel and Ken (Stanley) probably know a lot of them already.</div>
<div cla=
ss=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div clas=
s=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Oliver, you mentione=
d "<span style=3D"font-family:arial,sans-serif;font-size:13px;">some work h=
as probabilistically applied the objective function". I would be interested=
 to see this work if you find the link. If I remember correctly Jeff, JBM a=
nd Hod Lipson in "The evolutionary origins of modularity" used something si=
milar, but on the secondary objective (connection cost) objective.</span></=
div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></=
div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Best,</=
div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Vassilis</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br=
></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">
<br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">* N=
otes on CMA-ES:</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gma=
il_extra"><div class=3D"gmail_extra">In evolution strategies (ES) the mutat=
ion operator is usually the primary source of variation. Thus, we could say=
 that while selection exploits the fitness information in order to guide se=
arch into promising regions, mutation (or variation) explores the search sp=
ace and should not use any fitness information to do that, i.e., it should =
be unbiased. This is a theoretical consideration/requirement (called "unbia=
sedness"), which naturally leads to the maximum entropy principle. In the c=
ase of real-valued search spaces this leads to gaussian distributions, whil=
e it has been also shown in the literature how to potentially handle intege=
r and discrete parameters.</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div =
class=3D"gmail_extra">Let's stay on real-valued spaces and let's say that a=
n individual "a" comprises an object parameter vector "x", and its fitness =
function value "F(x)": a =3D (x, F(x)). Mutations on x work like this:</div=
>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">x' =3D x =
+ z</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">wi=
th z being related to gaussian distributions. </div><div class=3D"gmai=
l_extra"><br>
</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">The simplest case is z =3D s=
igma * ( N_1(0,1), N_2(0,1), ... , N_d(0,1) ), where sigma is the standard =
deviation of the normal distribution, d is the dimensionality, and N_i(0,1)=
 are independent random samples from the normal distribution.</div>
<div cl=
ass=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">People have notice=
d that when sigma is constant and the very simple (1+1)-ES is use=
d (meaning 1 parent creates 1 offspring and the strongest of them survives)=
, then in very simplified unimodal fitness functions (such as the sphere fu=
nction), the ES initially displays a period of improvements; however, =
after a while it becomes very very slow and loses its evolvability because =
when approaching the minimum sigma is too big and tends to overshoot. By an=
alyzing how sigma influences the success probability by which an offspring =
replaces a parent, as well as the progress rate, people have come up with s=
omething called the "evolution window" as well as the 1/5th control rule th=
at appropriately scales sigma periodically.</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra=
"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Now, the 1/5th rule is a heuristic a=
nd very specific to (1+1)-ES and the fitness landscape, so people needed so=
mething better. Hence the following idea: </div><div class=3D"gmail_ex=
tra">
<br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Let's add an endogenous/evolvabl=
e strategy parameter vector "s" to the individual, that contains any other =
parameters we want (such as the standard deviation). So now an individual i=
s: a =3D (x,s,F(x)). But how do we update sigma / the standard deviation? H=
ow do we mutate this mutation strength/rate? The maximum entropy principle =
specifies that we should use gaussian distributions, but using these on the=
 standard deviation could lead to negative values. A neat solution is to do=
 it in log scale:</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"=
gmail_extra">ln( sigma' ) =3D ln( sigma ) + zeta</div><div class=3D"gmail_e=
xtra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">which leads to the multiplicativ=
e update:</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">
<br></div><div class=3D"gmail_ex=
tra">sigma' =3D sigma * exp( zeta )</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></d=
iv><div class=3D"gmail_extra">where zeta =3D tau * N(0,1), and tau is an ex=
ogenous learning parameter which determines the rate and precision of self-=
adaptation. It is usually proportional to 1/sqrt(d).</div>
<div class=3D"gm=
ail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Until now we were talking a=
bout a single strategy parameter (mutation rate) for the whole genotype, i.=
e., s =3D sigma, also known as isotropic mutations. We can extend this to t=
he case where we have a vector of strategy parameters (mutation rates), i.e=
., s =3D (sigma_1, sigma_2, ..., sigma_d), also known as non-isotropic muta=
tions. This technique is more flexible especially in high dimensional probl=
ems. However, it is still not very effective in some non-separable problems=
, e.g., consider a fitness landscape that is not aligned with the coordinat=
e system. How do we deal with arbitrary rotations of the fitness landscape,=
 which is the most general situation?</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br>=
</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">Now the idea of Covariance Matrix Adaptati=
on is introduced: let's estimate the shape of the fitness landscape and ada=
pt a rotation matrix in order to be able to align our coordinate axes with =
the principal axes of the fitness landscape. This covariance matrix introdu=
ces correlations between the components of z.</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_ext=
ra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">So, in:</div><div class=3D"gmail_e=
xtra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">1) isotropic mutations: z =3D si=
gma * ( N_1(0,1), N_2(0,1), ... , N_d(0,1) ) =3D sigma * N(0, I), where I i=
s the identity matrix</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=
=3D"gmail_extra">2) non-isotropic mutations: z =3D ( sigma_1 * N_1(0,1), si=
gma_2 * N_2(0,1), ..., sigma_d * N_d(0,1) ) =3D D * N(0, I), where D is a d=
iagonal matrix containing all sigma values</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"=
><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">3) correlated mutations: z =3D M * ( =
sigma_1 * N_1(0,1), sigma_2 * N_2(0,1), ..., sigma_d * N_d(0,1) ) =3D M * D=
 * N(0, I), where M is the rotation matrix that introduces correlations bet=
ween the components of z, and C =3D M^T * M is the covariance matrix (M^T i=
s the transpose of M).</div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div clas=
s=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra">I won't get into mor=
e detail (e.g., how to estimate the covariance matrix etc.), but note that =
CMA-ES has been shown to work very well in various benchmarks and with smal=
l population sizes.</div>
</div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br></div></div>=

    </div>
